items.title: the new version 0.4.1 causes pyhive stuck
items.body:
when downgrade to v0.3.0 the problem is gone.

how to reproduce:
```
from pyhive import hive

conn = hive.Connection(host='YOUR_HOST', port=10000, auth='LDAP', username='xx', password='yy', database='default')

def exec(sql):
    cursor = raw_c.cursor()
    cursor.execute(sql)
    cursor.fetchall()

exec('YOUR_SQL')
```

stack trace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "testdb.py", line 42, in <module>
    exec('YOUR_SQL')
  File "testdb.py", line 30, in raw_exec
    cursor.fetchall()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyhive/common.py", line 136, in fetchall
    return list(iter(self.fetchone, None))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyhive/common.py", line 105, in fetchone
    self._fetch_while(lambda: not self._data and self._state != self._STATE_FINISHED)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyhive/common.py", line 45, in _fetch_while
    self._fetch_more()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pyhive/hive.py", line 386, in _fetch_more
    response = self._connection.client.FetchResults(req)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/TCLIService.py", line 714, in FetchResults
    return self.recv_FetchResults()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/TCLIService.py", line 733, in recv_FetchResults
    result.read(iprot)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/TCLIService.py", line 3470, in read
    self.success.read(iprot)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/ttypes.py", line 6583, in read
    self.results.read(iprot)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/ttypes.py", line 2867, in read
    _elem115.read(iprot)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/ttypes.py", line 2741, in read
    self.stringVal.read(iprot)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/TCLIService/ttypes.py", line 2521, in read
    _elem95 = iprot.readString().decode('utf-8') if sys.version_info[0] == 2 else iprot.readString()
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/thrift/protocol/TProtocol.py", line 185, in readString
    return binary_to_str(self.readBinary())
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/thrift/protocol/TBinaryProtocol.py", line 234, in readBinary
    s = self.trans.readAll(size)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/thrift/transport/TTransport.py", line 62, in readAll
    chunk = self.read(sz - have)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thrift_sasl/__init__.py", line 173, in read
    self._read_frame()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thrift_sasl/__init__.py", line 177, in _read_frame
    header = self._trans.read(4)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.6/site-packages/thrift/transport/TSocket.py", line 126, in read
    buff = self.handle.recv(sz)    # got stuck here
```

items.title: the new version 0.4.1 will cause pandas read_sql() stuck
items.body:
**import pandas as pd
hql="select * from test_tb"
pd.read_sql(hql, hive_conn)**

the code above will stuck in read_sql step.
and at the version 0.3.0 it will be ok

items.title: New release in pip
items.body:
Hi!

It would be nice to have a new release in pip with the changes of #14 Merged PR! Currently the latest version in pip (0.4a1) doesn't works with Python 3.x because of that!


Thanks!


Cheers
Felipe!

items.title: Pull request #17 to encode body as byte sequence introduces a regression in python 2.
items.body:
https://github.com/cloudera/thrift_sasl/pull/17 introduced a regression for python 2.x.
```
Python 2.7.10 (default, Aug 17 2018, 19:45:58)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 10.0.0 (clang-1000.0.42)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import impala.dbapi as impyla
>>> c = impyla.connect('<redacted hostname>', auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', use_ssl=True)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/tmp/impyla/lib/python2.7/site-packages/impala/dbapi.py", line 150, in connect
    http_path=http_path)
  File "/tmp/impyla/lib/python2.7/site-packages/impala/hiveserver2.py", line 825, in connect
    transport.open()
  File "/Users/dknupp/Documents/code/thrift_sasl/thrift_sasl/__init__.py", line 88, in open
    self._send_message(self.OK, initial_response)
  File "/Users/dknupp/Documents/code/thrift_sasl/thrift_sasl/__init__.py", line 109, in _send_message
    body = body.encode()
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x82 in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)
```
Under python 2, when the body is plain ASCII, calling encode() doesn't present an issue.
```
>>> 'foo'.encode()
'foo'
```
However, since the body is not always ASCII, we wind up with:
```
>>> '\x82'.encode()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x82 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```
I suspect that the preferred fix to the original issue should be to use bytearray():
 ```
  def _send_message(self, status, body):
    header = struct.pack(">BI", status, len(body))
    if isinstance(body, str):
      body = bytearray(body)
    self._trans.write(header + body)
    self._trans.flush()
```
Test using python 2.7.10
```
Python 2.7.10 (default, Aug 17 2018, 19:45:58)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 10.0.0 (clang-1000.0.42)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import impala.dbapi as impyla
>>> c = impyla.connect('<redacted hostname>', auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', use_ssl=True)
>>> cursor = c.cursor()
>>> cursor.execute('show databases')
>>> cursor.fetchall()
[('_impala_builtins', 'System database for Impala builtin functions'), ('default', 'Default Hive database')]
>>>
```
Test using python 3.7.2
```
Python 3.7.2 (default, Jan 13 2019, 12:50:01)
[Clang 10.0.0 (clang-1000.11.45.5)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import impala.dbapi as impyla
>>> c = impyla.connect('<redacted hostname>', auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', use_ssl=True)
>>> cursor = c.cursor()
>>> cursor.execute('show databases')
>>> cursor.fetchall()
[('_impala_builtins', 'System database for Impala builtin functions'), ('default', 'Default Hive database')]
>>>
```

items.title: TSaslClientTransport._send_message cannot concat str to bytes
items.body:
When connecting to Hive through Impyla with mechanism 'GSSAPI' the `_send_message` method fails when trying to concatenate the string 'GSSAPI' to the header bytes. The solution for this (widely spread across the web) is to insert a type check and conversion for the `body`  argument as follows:

```
  def _send_message(self, status, body):
    header = struct.pack(">BI", status, len(body))
    if isinstance(body, str):
        body = body.encode()
    self._trans.write(header + body)
    self._trans.flush()
```
It would seem based on the `__init__` docstring that the expected behavior is to accept strings for the `mechanism` argument.  However, I'm not exactly sure how this is intended to work without converting to bytes when it is passed to `_send_message`. 

We would like to use thrift_sasl in a production system, but would rather rely on the cloudera distribution than an internally maintained distribution for just 2 lines of code. Would it be possible to include this change in any upcoming releases?

items.title: AttributeError: 'TSocket' object has no attribute 'is_open'
items.body:
The removal of isOpen breaks backwards compatibility with older versions of Thrift, it will throw errors at is_open:

`/home/datascience/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/thrift_sasl/__init__.py in open(self)
     65 
     66   def open(self):
---> 67     if not self._trans.is_open():
     68       self._trans.open()
     69 

AttributeError: 'TSocket' object has no attribute 'is_open'
`
This is linked to this commit:
https://github.com/cloudera/thrift_sasl/commit/892ead18c163eec873fab68d7409053f50a8f0df

Reverting back to an older tag (v0.3.0) seems to get around this problem.

items.title: Troubleshooting Kerberos connection to Impala
items.body:
Hi,

Maybe I'm hitting a bug with thrift-sasl-0.3.0 when I try to connect to Impala with a kerberos token. 
I got this error with instanciation on connect  object.
For the following connect statement:
connect(host='host_impala', port=21050, auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', database='my_db', kerberos_service_name='impala')

My script return 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c.py", line 2, in <module>
    conn = connect(host='bda1node05.int.adeo.com', port=21050, auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', database='dataiku', kerberos_service_name='impala')
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/impala/dbapi.py", line 147, in connect
    auth_mechanism=auth_mechanism)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/impala/hiveserver2.py", line 758, in connect
    transport.open()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/thrift_sasl/__init__.py", line 67, in open
    if not self._trans.isOpen():
AttributeError: 'TSocket' object has no attribute 'isOpen'

The version used is: 
Name: thrift-sasl
Version: 0.3.0
Summary: Thrift SASL Python module that implements SASL transports for Thrift (`TSaslClientTransport`).
Home-page: https://github.com/cloudera/thrift_sasl
Author: Wes McKinney
Author-email: wes@cloudera.com
License: Apache License, Version 2.0
Location: /usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages
Requires: sasl, thrift

But I havn't any problem with 0.2.1 version:
pip3 install thrift_sasl==0.2.1
Collecting thrift_sasl==0.2.1
Requirement already satisfied: sasl>=0.2.1 in /usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages (from thrift_sasl==0.2.1)
Requirement already satisfied: thriftpy in /usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages (from thrift_sasl==0.2.1)
Requirement already satisfied: six in /usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages (from sasl>=0.2.1->thrift_sasl==0.2.1)
Requirement already satisfied: ply<4.0,>=3.4 in /usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages (from thriftpy->thrift_sasl==0.2.1)
Installing collected packages: thrift-sasl
  Found existing installation: thrift-sasl 0.3.0
    Uninstalling thrift-sasl-0.3.0:
      Successfully uninstalled thrift-sasl-0.3.0
Successfully installed thrift-sasl-0.2.1

And my script work fine.

items.title: PyPI currently hosts older version
items.body: This repo hosts newer version of the code which doesn't depend on `thriftpy`. Could you publish it to PyPI?

items.title: New release
items.body:
Can there be a new release?
At this point I have to install from straight from git to avoid issues like

```
    216     def readI32(self):
--> 217         buff = self.trans.readAll(4)
    218         val, = unpack('!i', buff)
    219         return val

AttributeError: 'TSaslClientTransport' object has no attribute 'readAll'
```

I guess there are similar issues around since [dropbox/PyHive](https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive) repo has that in [req file](https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/blob/master/dev_requirements.txt):
```
git+https://github.com/cloudera/thrift_sasl  # Using master branch in order to get Python 3 SASL patches
```

With latest commit works fine,
Thanks

items.title: TTransportException
items.body:
Hi, I am trying to connect to our Hadoop Cluster with Impyla. I have installed all dependencies. I encounter this error message.

``` python
C:\Anaconda\lib\site-packages\impala\dbapi.pyc in connect(host, port, database, timeout, use_ssl, ca_cert, auth_mechanism, user, password, kerberos_service_name, use_ldap, ldap_user, ldap_password, use_kerberos, protocol)
     83                           ca_cert=ca_cert, user=user, password=password,
     84                           kerberos_service_name=kerberos_service_name,
---> 85                           auth_mechanism=auth_mechanism)
     86     return hs2.HiveServer2Connection(service, default_db=database)
     87 

C:\Anaconda\lib\site-packages\impala\hiveserver2.pyc in connect(host, port, timeout, use_ssl, ca_cert, user, password, kerberos_service_name, auth_mechanism)
    566     transport = get_transport(sock, host, kerberos_service_name,
    567                               auth_mechanism, user, password)
--> 568     transport.open()
    569     protocol = TBinaryProtocol(transport)
    570     if six.PY2:

C:\Anaconda\lib\site-packages\thrift_sasl\__init__.pyc in open(self)
     70     if not ret:
     71       raise TTransportException(type=TTransportException.NOT_OPEN,
---> 72         message=("Could not start SASL: %s" % self.sasl.getError()))
     73 
     74     # Send initial response

TTransportException: Could not start SASL: Error in sasl_client_start (-4) SASL(-4): no mechanism available: Unable to find a callback: 2 
```

I am creating the client this way:

``` python
conn = connect(host='', port=21050, auth_mechanism='GSSAPI', database='name_db', 
               user='user_name', password='pswd')
```

So I am wondering where could be the problem, I am running on WIN8 so am I still missing some dependencies?
